Integral representation of solutions to
initial-boundary value problems in the
framework of the hyperbolic heat equation
Sergey A. Rukolaine∗
Ioﬀe Institute, 26 Polytekhnicheskaya, St. Petersburg 194021, Russia
Abstract
We consider initial-boundary value problems on a ﬁnite interval for the system of
the energy balance equation and modiﬁed Fourier’s law (constitutive equation, com-
monly called the Cattaneo equation) describing temperature (or internal energy) and
heat ﬂux. This hyperbolic system of ﬁrst-order partial diﬀerential equations is the
simplest model of non-Fourier heat conduction. Boundary conditions comprise var-
ious models of behavior of a physical system at the boundaries, including boundary
conditions describing Newton’s law, which states that the heat ﬂux at the boundary
is directly proportional to the diﬀerence in the temperature of the physical system
and ambient temperature. In this case the boundary conditions express the rela-
tionship of unknown functions (temperature or internal energy and heat ﬂux) with
each other. To solve the problems, we apply the Fokas uniﬁed transform method.
Keywords: non-Fourier heat conduction, Cattaneo equation, modiﬁed Fourier’s
law, hyperbolic heat equation, initial-boundary value problems, Fokas uniﬁed trans-
form method
1
Introduction
The heat equation
∂tT −α∆T = 0,
(1.1)
where T is temperature, and α is thermal diﬀusivity, is commonly used for description of
heat conduction in homogeneous isotropic media. The heat equation is obtained from the
energy balance equation
Cv∂tT + ∇· q = 0
(1.2)
and Fourer’s law (the constitutive equation)
q = −κ∇T,
(1.3)
where Cv is volumetric heat capacity, q is the vector of heat ﬂux, and κ is thermal
conductivity. Hence the thermal diﬀusivity is given by α = κ/Cv.
The energy balance equation (1.2) exactly expresses the ﬁrst law of thermodynamics
as applied to heat transfer: the conservation of thermal energy. Fourier’s law, in turn, is
∗E-mail address: rukol@ammp.ioffe.ru
1


approximate relation between the heat ﬂux and temperature. Fourier’s law can be con-
sidered as a phenomenological relation. In classical irreversible (weakly non-equilibrium
or linear non-equilibrium) thermodynamics Fourier’s law is derived under the assumption
of local thermodynamic equilibrium [1–3]. However, this assumption is violated in very
small dimensions and short timescales, and at low temperatures [4–11]. Besides, the heat
equation violates the causality principle due to inﬁnite speed of heat propagation in this
model.
The simplest and apparently most “famous” modiﬁcation of Fourer’s law is given by
the constitutive equation
τ∂tq + q = −κ∇T,
(1.4)
where τ is the relaxation time. This equation is usually attributed to Cattaneo [4] or even
to Maxwell, Cattaneo and Vernotte [12, 13]. However, Cattaneo’s priority is question-
able [5, 14], see also Ref.[15]. Therefore, we will call this equation modiﬁed Fourier’s law.
The constitutive equation (1.4) is the ﬁrst and simplest constitutive equation obtained
in the framework of various extended thermodynamics: rational extended thermodynam-
ics [16], extended irreversible thermodynamics [17] and non-equilibrium thermodynamics
with internal variables [18], see also Ref. [19].
It follows from the energy balance equation (1.2) and the modiﬁed Fourier’s law (1.4)
that temperature satisﬁes the so called hyperbolic heat equation
τ∂2
t T + ∂tT −α∆T = 0.
(1.5)
Since this equation is hyperbolic, it provides a ﬁnite speed of heat propagation and there-
fore satisﬁes the causality principle.
Solving initial value problems (in the entire space) for this and other equations ob-
tained in the framework of extended thermodynamics and analysing their solutions is
straightforward [20–22]. However, solving initial-boundary value problems (IBVPs) an-
alytically may encounter diﬃculties. Below, for simplicity, we will consider equations in
one-dimensional space. Also, we will consider problems on a ﬁnite interval. Problems on
the half line can be solved in the same way.
In one-dimensional space the hyperbolic heat equation (1.5) takes the form
τ∂2
t T + ∂tT −α∂2
xT = 0.
(1.6)
If both boundary conditions set the temperature behavior, then the IBVP can easily be
solved by the Fourier method or Laplace transform. If both boundary conditions set the
heat ﬂux behavior, then the analytical solution for temperature can also be easily found.
Indeed, heat ﬂux satisﬁes the same equation as temperature:
τ∂2
t q + ∂tq −α∂2
xq = 0.
(1.7)
First, the IBVP for this equation is solved, and then temperature is determined using the
energy balance equation (1.2) (in one dimension).
However, other boundary conditions may be set as well, e. g., one or both boundary
conditions can describe Newton’s law (convection boundary conditions), which states that
the heat ﬂux at the boundary is directly proportional to the diﬀerence in the temperature
of the physical system and ambient temperature. In this case IBVPs cannot be formulated
for either equation (1.6) or equation (1.7). In this case IBVPs should be formulated for
the system of the energy balance equation (1.2) and the constitutive equation (1.4) (both
2


in one dimension if we stay in one-dimensional space).
And in this case, the Fourier
method is not applicable.
Application of the Laplace transform to these problems is
problematic as well. All these problems can be solved by the Fokas uniﬁed transform
method (UTM) [23–36]. In this paper we solve these IBVPs by the UTM. The UTM
was applied to systems of equations in Refs. [26, 30, 31, 33–35]. The peculiarity of the
problems considered in this paper is that the boundary conditions generally express the
relationship of unknown functions (temperature and heat ﬂux) with each other.
In the papers [13, 37–40] the IBVPs in the framework of the hyperbolic heat equation
were solved both analytically and numerically for particular boundary conditions.
2
Statement of the initial-boundary value problem
We consider the IBVP for the system of the energy balance equation (including the
heat source term) and modiﬁed Fourier’s law on the interval (0, l). For convenience, we
consider internal energy e = CvT instead of temperature T.
Therefore, we solve the
system of the equations
∂te + ∂xq = f(x, t),
x ∈(0, l),
t > 0,
(2.1a)
τ∂tq + q + α∂xe = 0,
x ∈(0, l),
t > 0,
(2.1b)
where f is the heat source term. The system (2.1) is hyperbolic. Initial conditions for the
system (2.1) set the initial state of the physical system and are given by
e|t=0 = ϕ(x),
q|t=0 = ψ(x).
(2.2)
The boundary conditions are given by
(γ0e + δ0q)|x=0 = g(t),
(γle + δlq)|x=l = h(t),
(2.3)
where |γ0| + |δ0| > 0 and |γl| + |δl| > 0. The general form of the boundary conditions
allows us to describe diﬀerent behavior of the physical system at the boundary: we can
set the temperature or heat ﬂux at the boundary; these boundary conditions also include
Newton’s law, which states that the heat ﬂux at the boundary is directly proportional
to the diﬀerence in the temperature of the physical system and ambient temperature.
We assume that the initial and boundary conditions are consistent with each other if
necessary.

5
Conclusions
In this paper we have considered the IBVPs on the ﬁnite interval for the system of
the energy balance equation and modiﬁed Fourier’s law (constitutive equation).

system is hyperbolic. The boundary conditions include various models of behavior of a
physical system at the boundaries. The most interesting model is when the behavior on
at least one of the boundaries is described by Newton’s law, which states that the heat
ﬂux at the boundary is directly proportional to the diﬀerence in the temperature of the
physical system and ambient temperature. In this case the boundary conditions express
the relationship of unknown functions (temperature or internal energy and heat ﬂux) with
each other.
To solve the problems, we have applied the uniﬁed transform method. We did not solve
problems in which one of the boundary conditions determines the temperature. These
problems can be solved in the same way as in this paper. To illustrate the ﬁnal formulae,
we have considered a numerical example for a special case in which heat exchange at one
of the boundaries obeys Newton’s law.
Also of considerable interest is the integral representation of solutions to IBVPs in the
framework of the Guyer–Krumhansl model of heat conduction [4, 5, 17, 41, 42]. In the
papers [37, 38, 40, 43–45] the IBVPs in the framework of the Guyer–Krumhansl model
were solved both analytically and numerically for particular boundary conditions. The
integral representation of the solutions to the initial value problems in the framework of
the Guyer–Krumhansl model will be considered elsewhere.

metadata.title: Integral representation of solutions to initial-boundary value problems in the framework of the hyperbolic heat equation
metadata.abstract:
We consider initial-boundary value problems on a finite interval for the
system of the energy balance equation and modified Fourier's law (constitutive
equation, commonly called the Cattaneo equation) describing temperature (or
internal energy) and heat flux. This hyperbolic system of first-order partial
differential equations is the simplest model of non-Fourier heat conduction.
Boundary conditions comprise various models of behavior of a physical system at
the boundaries, including boundary conditions describing Newton's law, which
states that the heat flux at the boundary is directly proportional to the
difference in the temperature of the physical system and ambient temperature.
In this case the boundary conditions express the relationship of unknown
functions (temperature or internal energy and heat flux) with each other. To
solve the problems, we apply the Fokas unified transform method.
